_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Mid-Missouri Energy Inc.  (Facility ID: 100000195362)



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:



The Mid-Missouri Energy, Inc. (MME) Ethanol Plant is located near Malta Bend, Saline County, Missouri.



The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from grain. Processes involved in this activity include a) the receiving and milling of corn, b) liquefaction of the milled corn to produce mash, c) fermentation of the mash to produce beer, d) distillation of the beer to produce ethanol, and e) denaturing of the ethanol.  



The regulated substances under the RMP program are Anhydrous Ammonia and Denaturant (natural gasoline) which is considered a flammable mixture. Denaturant is added to the ethanol at the end of the process so the ethanol can not be consumed. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and used in the liquefaction process to adjust pH levels.  The maximum quantity of ammonia stored would be 83,508 pounds in one 18,000 gallon storage tank and one 1,000 gallon nurse tank.  



MME has determined that the radius of impact from a worst-case release would be approximately 1.5 miles; due to the amount of ammonia stored on site.  The radius of impact for a worst-case denaturant release is approximately 0.5 miles.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:



MME is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel as well as considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility.



MME's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary. The two ethanol tanks, two final product tanks, and denaturant tank are all located in a large bermed tank fa

rm containment area that is separated from the plant.  A release from one of these tanks would not be able to migrate off-site, and a fire resulting from a release could be quickly extinguished.  



The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Standards of the U. S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia" and the Standards of OSHA, 29 CFR 1910.119 "Process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals." The anhydrous ammonia tank is located outside and equipped with remotely actuated emergency shut off valves and excess flow shut off valves.  The process building, where the ammonia is used, is ventilated, has high ceilings and large volume into which the lighter than air ammonia vapor to move above the operating floor and personnel. 



Administrative controls for both the denaturant and ammonia include following good engineering practices for maintenance of the systems as designed and installed. Also, administrative controls include following written operating procedures, and to utilize specified personal protective equipment (PPE) for tasks when potential for exposure exists. MME conducts employee training as part of facility activities. Lastly, operations at both the tank farm and anhydrous ammonia tank can be overseen from the Control Room. 



Facility personnel at MME are not trained to be first responders to large incidents on-site. MME has coordinated with the Malta Bend Fire Department as well as the Marshall Fire Department for emergency response procedures.  MME has also contracted with a private hazmat company (Hazmat Response) based in Kansas City, Missouri. If a release were to occur the following response practices are to be implemented: 



INCIDENTAL RELEASES (Small Discharge Scenario)



A release is an incidental release and

does not require immediately notifying the Plant Manager or the EH&S Manager if the following is true:



* The released hazardous substance can be absorbed or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees or other trained persons present.

* The release is either inside or outside facility buildings, within secondary containment, on an impervious surface and does not reach pervious surfaces (i.e., soil) or storm water drainage.

* The released hazardous material is less than 25 gallons.

* The release would not have posed a threat to human health and the environment if the release had not been immediately controlled.

        

In response to an incidental release, the following steps will be taken:



1.    If an employee observes a release, the employee will immediately notify a supervisor who will assess the release.  The employee and/or supervisor may attempt to stop the flow of product if doing so poses no threat or harm.  If the supervisor decides the release does not constitute a threat to human health or the environment and does not require assistance by personnel outside the immediate area of the spill, then clean-up will begin.

2.    The supervisor or assigned trained personnel will clean-up the spill.  Employees or trained personnel cleaning up the spill will be attired in the necessary protective equipment (i.e., goggles, rubber gloves, boots, etc.).  If necessary, clean-up will be preceded by an attempt to stop the discharge, restricting traffic through the spill area, and limiting migration of the release by laying berms of absorbent materials.

3.    The supervisor or trained personnel will absorb the released material with appropriate disposable materials.  The plant has speedi-dry, sand, and spill kits readily available. 

4.    The contaminated absorbent will be containerized, labeled, and disposed of properly.

5.    Materials such as gloves that were contaminated as a result of the release will also be containerized, labeled, and disposed.  These materi

als are typically considered a regulated waste and cannot be disposed with the facility's other waste.  Also liquid waste can never be poured down a drain.  

6.    The EH&S Manager or the Plant Manager will ensure no waste incompatible with released materials is treated, stored, or disposed of at the facility until the clean-up is complete.

7.    The EH&S Manager or the Plant Manager will ensure emergency equipment listed in this Plan is cleaned and fit for its intended use before operations at the facility resume.

8.    The EH&S Manager or the Plant Manager will check for leaks, pressure buildup, gas generation, or ruptures in valves, pipes or other equipment before operations resume.



MEDIUM DISCHARGE AND WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS



A release is considered non-incidental if it has one or more of the following criteria: 



* The released substance cannot be absorbed or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees or other trained persons present.

* The release is either outside facility buildings on a pervious surface or inside and may reach pervious surfaces (i.e., soil), or storm water drainage.

* The released material is more than 25 gallons.

* The release may pose a threat to human health and the environment if the release is not immediately controlled.



The following describe procedures for non-incidental hazardous releases:



Upon detection of the release, the discovering employee will immediately notify a supervisor.  If the supervisor assesses that clean-up efforts would require the assistance of personnel from beyond the immediate area of the spill, then the supervisor will notify the EH&S Manager or the Plant Manager and the Control Room that there has been a large release.  The supervisor will also relate the extent of or potential for migration of the spill to the environment.  The supervisor may attempt to stop the flow of product if doing so poses no personal threat or harm.  Once notified, the EH&S Manager or the Plant Manager will

act as the Coordinator for managing the release and will then take the following steps:



1.    The Coordinator may decide to evacuate the building or facility, in which case an announcement will be made over the radios.

2.    The Coordinator will assess the secondary containment, decide whether the product can be reclaimed, and decide whether the emergency response contractor and MoDNR 24-hr spill response hotline (573-634-2436) need to be notified.  If deemed necessary, the Fire Department (911), Police Department (911), and/or the local hospital will also be notified.

3.    The Coordinator may direct the use of the onsite heavy equipment to create soil berms/swales halting the movement of the spill and the placement of available spill response materials.  This should simply halt the flow of product and not direct it into drainage structures.  The Coordinator may direct the movement of product into additional storage vessels or decide to contact a licensed spill response company.  

4.    The Coordinator will try to identify the character, amount, source, and extent of the release as well as assess the real or potential threats to human health or the environment from this release. 

5.    If the Coordinator believes there exists a threat to human health or the environment outside of the facility and evacuation of local areas may become necessary, then the Coordinator will notify the local authorities as well as the National Response Center at 1-800-424 8802 and MoDNR at 573-634-2436.

6.    The Coordinator will ensure no waste incompatible with released materials is treated, stored, or disposed of at the facility until the clean-up is complete.

7.    The Coordinator will ensure emergency equipment listed in the Plan is cleaned and fit for its intended use before operations at the facility resume.

8.    The Coordinator will monitor for leaks, pressure buildup, gas generation, or ruptures in valves, pipes or other equipment before operations resume.

9.    Contaminated materials resulti

ng from the clean-up will be containerized, labeled, and disposed of properly.  These materials are typically considered a regulated waste and cannot be disposed with the facility's trash.  Also, liquid waste can never be poured down a drain.  

10.    The Coordinator will complete and submit the proper spill forms and reports required by state and federal agencies.



Both the truck and railcar loading/loadout areas have been equipped with containment devices. The truck loadout area is concrete and designed to direct the flow of potential spills to drains under this area. The drains are then directed into the tank farm's secondary containment area. A catchment basin is also located immediately below the railcar loadout. A spill to the railcar loadout catchment basin also drains back to the tank farm secondary containment via underground piping. Spill response materials are available throughout the facility to deal with minor spillage, as necessary. Spills shall be cleaned and removed promptly by trained employees. 



ADDITIONAL INFORMATION SPECIFIC TO ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



Unlike spills of other liquid products, anhydrous ammonia will immediately evaporate at ambient temperature and pressure. It will not travel overland and into drainage systems at the plant. Therefore, traditional spill containment practices will not work in responding to the release. Facility employees are not trained as first responders for an anhydrous ammonia release and the local Fire Dept. (911) or emergency contractor should be contacted. To prevent exposure employees should:



* Stay upwind of a spill or threatened release. Although ammonia vapors are lighter than air in some cases ammonia will hug the ground and drift. 

* Ammonia has excellent warning properties which may allow escape before concentrations affect health. Many people can detect ammonia odor at 1 to 5 parts per million which is a hundred times less than what is immediately dangerous to life and health. 

* Preplan your escap

e route prior to working near anhydrous ammonia. 

* Carefully approach with the wind at your back or perpendicular to incident source. 

* If ammonia vapors are drifting across a road, no vehicles should be permitted to drive into the cloud.

* Shelter in place or evacuate those residences down wind depending upon the expected ammonia air concentrations.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS:



The worst case scenario at the facility is the release of 79,113 pounds of anhydrous ammonia creating a toxic cloud.  The worst-case scenario is based on the release of all ammonia stored on site.  The worst case vapor cloud endpoint is approximately 3.3 miles from the center of the plant.  Public receptors are located within this radius. For denaturant the worst-case scenario at the facility is the release of 725,580 pounds of denaturant creating a vapor cloud explosion.  The worst-case scenario is based on a release from the entire denaturant tank.  The worst case vapor cloud endpoint is approximately 0.6 miles from the center of the facility.  Public receptors are also located within the radius.

  

Although MME has numerous controls in place to prevent such a release and to manage potential consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario.



Since MME qualifies as a Program 3 due to the close proximity of public receptors, Program Safety Management has been completed for this facility.



Since the facility also qualifies as a Program 3, Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) were required.  The ARS is the release of 1000 pounds of denaturant creating a vapor cloud explosion.  The ARS endpoint is approximately 0.06 miles from the center of the facility.  The ARS is the toxic release of 200 pounds per minute of ammonia.  The ARS endpoint is approximately 0.1 miles from the center of the facility.  There are no public receptors within these radiuses that would be affected by the altern

ative releases.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or denaturant in the past five years that: Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the continuation of safe conditions. Updates to OSHA regulations, as well as other regulatory updates, are received by email and postal mail to be evaluated by staff regularly. MME conducts monthly safety meetings where recommendations for improvements are discussed and implemented. MME has completed all of the recommended improvements to the safety program based on this inspection.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION:



MME is registered with the Saline County, MO LEPC and does not have its own Emergency Response Plan for emergencies requiring a high level of emergency support. In the case that an incident occurred which required high level emergency response, MME would call 911 for the necessary fire, medical or other emergency support. 



As explained above, MME is committed to worker and public safety and has invested in training and equipment to prevent chemical spills and other emergency situations. In the event of a chemical spill, plant personnel would respond to contain the release, as necessary. Some physical aspects of the plant would also help the personnel contain a potential spill. For example, all tanks that contain denaturant are located in a large, bermed containment area that is separated from the plant.  A release from one of these tanks would be prevented from migrating off-site, and a fire could be extinguished before it spreads to other units at the facility.  In addition, a manual shut off valve in the ammonia tank would help limi

t the volume of an ammonia spill.



MME has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38. An FRP & SPCC Plan was also prepared and implemented for the denaturant and final product storage in accordance with applicable regulatory standards and timeframes. The following list provides a facility organizational chart with respect to RMP responsibilities. 

 

NAME            

1) Shawn Davis

2) Tyler Edmundson

3) Area Supervisors

4) Onsite Personnel & Contractors    



TITLE

1) EH&S Manager / Primary Response Coordinator

2) Plant Manager / Alternate Response Coordinator

3) Area Supervisors

4) Onsite Personnel & Contractors



REPORTS TO

1) Plant Manager & VP of Operations

2) VP of Operations & Board of Directors

3) Response Coordinators

4) Area Supervisors & Response Coordinators    



RESPONSIBILITIES

1) Oversight of RMP Implementation. Spill prevention, response recordkeeping, training, and inspections.

2) Overall RMP Implementation. Assist Primary Coordinator with responsibilities.

3) Assist Coordinators with RMP implementation & report incidents

4) Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents



MME's corporate policy places the utmost importance on worker, public and environmental safety, which is reflected in facility plans and training activities.
